column1: When a tumor grows it can press on nerves, bones, organs, or the spinal cord, causing pain.
Some medical tests, such as a biopsy or bone marrow test, can cause pain.
Many people with cancer do not get enough treatment for their pain.
Some people are afraid to take pain medicines because they think they will become addicted.
To make sure you get the right treatment for your pain, it is important to be as honest as possible with your provider.
These medicines include acetaminophen (Tylenol) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others), and naproxen (Aleve).
You may take these medicines in addition to other pain relievers.
These can include anticonvulsants or antidepressants for nerve pain or steroids to treat pain from swelling.
Some pain medicines can interact with other medicines.
In some cases, your provider may suggest another type of treatment for your cancer pain.
These medicines can also shrink a tumor to reduce pain.
You may also choose to try treatments such as acupuncture, mediation, or biofeedback to help treat your pain.
